conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The shape and size of the shadow depend on the shape of the object, the position of the light source, and the distance between the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
Initially, the shadows A, B, C, and D are cast by the objects on the ground.
The position and size of these shadows are determined by the current position of the light source.
When the light source moves forward, above the objects, the angle at which the light hits the objects changes.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward.
When the light source is directly above the objects, the shadows will be smaller because the light is hitting the objects more directly.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will elongate, becoming larger and more stretched out.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become larger as the light source moves forward, above the objects.
